verses.verse: God’s Everlasting Love What then shall we say to these things? (Num. 14:9) If God is for us, who can be against us?
(Rom. 5:6, 10) He who did not spare His own Son, but ((Rom. 4:25)) delivered Him up for us all, how shall He not with Him also freely give us all things?
Who shall bring a charge against God’s elect? (Is. 50:8, 9; Rev. 12:10) It is God who justifies.

(John 3:18) Who is he who condemns? It is Christ who died, and furthermore is also risen, (Mark 16:19; Col. 3:1; Heb. 1:3) who is even at the right hand of God, (Heb. 7:25; 9:24) who also makes intercession for us.
Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?
As it is written: (Ps. 44:22; Acts 20:24; 1 Cor. 4:9; 15:30; (2 Cor. 1:9; 4:10; 6:9; 11:23)) “For Your sake we are killed all day long; We are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.”
(John 16:33; 1 Cor. 15:57; 2 Cor. 2:14; 1 John 5:4) Yet in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.
For I am persuaded that neither death nor life, nor angels nor ((1 Cor. 15:24; Eph. 1:21; 1 Pet. 3:22)) principalities nor powers, nor things present nor things to come,
nor height nor depth, nor any other created thing, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Israel’s Rejection of Christ I (2 Cor. 1:23) tell the truth in Christ, I am not lying, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Spirit,
(Rom. 10:1) that I have great sorrow and continual grief in my heart.
For (Ex. 32:32) I could wish that I myself were accursed from Christ for my brethren, my countrymen according to the flesh,

who are Israelites, (Ex. 4:22; (Rom. 8:15)) to whom pertain the adoption, (1 Sam. 4:21) the glory, (Gen. 17:2; Deut. 29:14; Luke 1:72; Acts 3:25) the covenants, (Deut. 4:13; Ps. 147:19) the giving of the law, (Heb. 9:1, 6) the service of God, and ((Acts 2:39; 13:32; Eph. 2:12)) the promises;
(Deut. 10:15) of whom are the fathers and from ((Luke 1:34, 35; 3:23)) whom, according to the flesh, Christ came, (Jer. 23:6) who is over all, the eternally blessed God. Amen.
Israel’s Rejection and God’s Purpose (Num. 23:19) But it is not that the word of God has taken no effect. For ((John 8:39; Gal. 6:16)) they are not all Israel who are of Israel,
((John 8:33, 39; Gal. 4:23)) nor are they all children because they are the seed of Abraham; but, (Gen. 21:12; Heb. 11:18) “In Isaac your seed shall be called.”
That is, those who are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God; but (Gal. 4:28) the children of the promise are counted as the seed.
For this is the word of promise: (Gen. 18:10, 14; Heb. 11:11) “At this time I will come and Sarah shall have a son.”
And not only this, but when (Gen. 25:21) Rebecca also had conceived by one man, even by our father Isaac
(for the children not yet being born, nor having done any good or evil, that the purpose of God according to election might stand, not of works but of ((Rom. 4:17; 8:28)) Him who calls),
it was said to her, (Gen. 25:23) “The older shall serve the younger.”
As it is written, (Mal. 1:2, 3) “Jacob I have loved, but Esau I have hated.”
Israel’s Rejection and God’s Justice What shall we say then? (Deut. 32:4) Is there unrighteousness with God? Certainly not!
For He says to Moses, (Ex. 33:19) “I will have mercy on whomever I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whomever I will have compassion.”
So then it is not of him who wills, nor of him who runs, but of God who shows mercy.
For (Gal. 3:8) the Scripture says to the Pharaoh, (Ex. 9:16) “For this very purpose I have raised you up, that I may show My power in you, and that My name may be declared in all the earth.”
Therefore He has mercy on whom He wills, and whom He wills He (Ex. 4:21; Deut. 2:30; Josh. 11:20; John 12:40; Rom. 11:7, 25) hardens.
You will say to me then, “Why does He still find fault? For (2 Chr. 20:6; Job 9:12; Dan. 4:35) who has resisted His will?”
But indeed, O man, who are you to reply against God? (Is. 29:16; Jer. 18:6; Rom. 9:22; 2 Tim. 2:20) Will the thing formed say to him who formed it, “Why have you made me like this?”
Does not the (Prov. 16:4) potter have power over the clay, from the same lump to make (2 Tim. 2:20) one vessel for honor and another for dishonor?
What if God, wanting to show His wrath and to make His power known, endured with much longsuffering ((1 Thess. 5:9)) the vessels of wrath (Prov. 16:4; (1 Pet. 2:8)) prepared for destruction,
and that He might make known ((Col. 1:27)) the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy, which He had ((Rom. 8:28-30)) prepared beforehand for glory,
even us whom He ((Rom. 8:28)) called, (Is. 42:6, 7; 49:6; Luke 2:32; Rom. 3:29) not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles?
